confidenceLevels.high: Multiple RCTs, meta-analyses, or well-established research
confidenceLevels.medium: Some controlled studies, strong theoretical basis, or consistent clinical reports
confidenceLevels.low: Limited research, primarily phenomenological reports or extrapolation from related practices

vipassana.researchBasis: Extensive research through MBSR/MBCT derivatives; multiple meta-analyses

adhd.justification: Attention training component well-supported. Zylowska (2008) showed benefits for adult ADHD. However, requires sustained practice which can be challenging for ADHD population.
adhd.concerns: May be difficult to establish practice without support structures

depression.justification: Strong evidence from MBCT trials. Kuyken et al. (2016) meta-analysis shows equivalent to antidepressants for relapse prevention. Goyal et al. (2014) moderate effect sizes.

anxiety.justification: Robust evidence across multiple meta-analyses. Hofmann et al. (2010) showed moderate effect sizes for anxiety. Mechanism: decentering from anxious thoughts.

trauma.justification: Mixed evidence. Can be helpful for processing but may trigger overwhelm. Trauma-sensitive modifications (TCTSY) show better results. Not first-line treatment.
trauma.concerns: Risk of re-traumatization without proper support; needs trauma-informed adaptation

focus.justification: Well-established attention training effects. MacLean et al. (2010) shamatha retreat showed sustained attention improvements. Jha et al. (2007) showed attention improvements.

metacognition.justification: Core mechanism of vipassana is observing mental processes. Research shows increased metacognitive awareness. Teasdale et al. (2002) on decentering.

insight.justification: Traditional purpose of practice; 'vipassana' literally means insight. Phenomenological reports consistent with increased self-understanding.

compassion.justification: Secondary effect through reduced reactivity and increased equanimity. Often combined with metta practice. Less direct than loving-kindness meditation.
compassion.concerns: Score might be inflated; compassion not primary focus

communication.justification: Indirect benefits through reduced reactivity. No direct communication training component.

empathy.justification: Increased emotional awareness may enhance empathic accuracy. Klimecki et al. (2013) showed brain changes related to empathy.

bodyAwareness.justification: Body scanning is core practice. Increased interoceptive awareness well-documented. Farb et al. (2013) on interoception changes.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Primary mechanism: observing emotions without reactivity. Robustly supported. Goldin & Gross (2010) showed improved emotion regulation.

focusing.researchBasis: Good theoretical foundation, moderate empirical research, primarily in psychotherapy contexts

adhd.justification: No direct research. May help with emotional aspects of ADHD. Requires sustained introspection which may be challenging.

depression.justification: Hendricks (2009) meta-analysis of focusing in psychotherapy shows positive effects. Mechanism: accessing and processing implicit emotional content.

anxiety.justification: Strong theoretical fit - anxiety often involves disconnection from bodily knowing. Gendlin's research showed therapy outcomes improved with focusing ability.

trauma.justification: Excellent fit for trauma work - gentle, titrated approach to bodily experience. Shares principles with Somatic Experiencing. Used in trauma-informed therapy.

focus.justification: Not primarily an attention practice. Some concentration involved but not systematic attention training.
focus.concerns: Score may be accurate but not well-researched

metacognition.justification: Involves observing inner experience and its qualities. Develops awareness of pre-verbal knowing.
metacognition.concerns: Different type of metacognition than meditation-based

insight.justification: Core purpose of practice - accessing implicit knowing that emerges as 'felt shifts'. Well-documented phenomenologically.

compassion.justification: The 'friendly attending' stance toward inner experience cultivates self-compassion. Extends to others through similar listening.

communication.justification: Can improve listening skills through Focusing Partnerships. Not primary focus of practice.

empathy.justification: Focusing Partnerships explicitly develop empathic listening. Attunement to others' felt sense.

bodyAwareness.justification: Core of practice - attending to 'felt sense' in body. Interoceptive awareness is foundational skill.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Learning to be with difficult emotions without overwhelm. 'Clearing a space' technique specifically for regulation.

jhana.researchBasis: Traditional Buddhist texts, limited modern research, strong phenomenological consistency

adhd.justification: Systematically trains sustained attention. Brasington reports ADHD practitioners often excel. However, initial difficulty may be high.
adhd.concerns: Requires high initial motivation and skilled guidance

depression.justification: Access to jhanic joy/pleasure states may help counter anhedonia. However, not directly addressing cognitive patterns of depression.

anxiety.justification: Concentrated states reduce anxiety during practice, but may not transfer to daily life as well as insight practices.

trauma.justification: Deep concentration can suppress trauma material rather than process it. Not designed for trauma work.
trauma.concerns: May bypass important material; not therapeutic

focus.justification: Primary purpose is concentration development. Systematic progression through absorption states requires extreme focus.

metacognition.justification: High awareness of mental states required to navigate jhanic factors. However, insight-focused practices may be superior for this.

insight.justification: Traditional view: jhana provides stable platform for insight. But jhana itself is not insight practice.

compassion.justification: Some jhana practices use metta as object. But not primary purpose of concentration practice.

communication.justification: No direct relationship. Solitary practice.

empathy.justification: Increased equanimity may support empathy. No direct training.

bodyAwareness.justification: Whole-body awareness is key jhana factor. Pleasure suffuses body in higher jhanas.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Access to calm states on demand. Equanimity development. However, may be state-dependent.

mbsr.researchBasis: Most researched contemplative program; thousands of studies; multiple meta-analyses

adhd.justification: Zylowska (2008) adapted mindfulness for ADHD. MBSR not specifically designed for ADHD but provides attention training benefits.

depression.justification: Extensive evidence base. Grossman et al. (2004) meta-analysis. Not as specific as MBCT but strong effects.

anxiety.justification: Original development was for stress/anxiety. Robust evidence across populations. Hofmann et al. (2010) meta-analysis.

trauma.justification: Helpful but not trauma-specific. Body scan can be activating for trauma survivors. Trauma-sensitive modifications needed.

focus.justification: Attention training is core component. Well-documented attention improvements.

metacognition.justification: Develops observer perspective on thoughts and feelings. Central teaching of program.

insight.justification: Promotes self-understanding through sustained observation. Less emphasis than traditional vipassana.

compassion.justification: Some loving-kindness included. Self-compassion develops through non-judgmental attention.

communication.justification: Mindful communication mentioned but not primary focus. Some programs include it.

empathy.justification: Increased emotional awareness supports empathy. Healthcare worker studies show improved patient relationships.

bodyAwareness.justification: Body scan is foundational practice. Yoga component. Well-documented interoceptive changes.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Core outcome of program. Strong evidence for stress reduction translating to emotional regulation.

ifs.researchBasis: Growing evidence base; RCTs emerging; strong clinical acceptance

adhd.justification: May help with emotional dysregulation component of ADHD. No specific research on ADHD.

depression.justification: Parts work effective for depression. Addresses self-criticism through exile/protector framework. Growing RCT evidence.

anxiety.justification: Working with anxious parts and their protective functions. Effective clinical model.

trauma.justification: Excellent trauma model - allows titrated approach through parts. Schwartz developed specifically for complex trauma. Growing research support.

focus.justification: Some attention to internal experience but not systematic attention training.

metacognition.justification: Core skill is observing internal parts and their dynamics. Highly metacognitive framework.

insight.justification: Deep self-understanding through parts exploration. Origins and functions of patterns revealed.

compassion.justification: Self-compassion is core mechanism - 'Self' energy is inherently compassionate. Learning to relate kindly to all parts.

communication.justification: Less reactivity improves communication. Some applications to couples work.

empathy.justification: Understanding own parts helps understand others' parts. Extends compassionate framework outward.

bodyAwareness.justification: Parts often located in body but not primary somatic practice. Can integrate with somatic approaches.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Core outcome - less hijacking by parts, more Self-leadership. Well-documented clinical improvements.

somatic-experiencing.researchBasis: Moderate research; RCTs emerging; strong theoretical foundation in neuroscience

adhd.justification: May help with nervous system regulation but not specific ADHD intervention.

depression.justification: Depression often involves freeze/shutdown states. SE addresses nervous system regulation.

anxiety.justification: Directly addresses sympathetic arousal. Pendulation and titration core techniques. Growing evidence base.

trauma.justification: Designed specifically for trauma. Addresses physiological imprint. RCTs show effectiveness for PTSD.

focus.justification: Requires attending to sensations but not systematic attention training.

metacognition.justification: Develops awareness of body states but less cognitive metacognition than mindfulness.

insight.justification: Understanding emerges through body. Trauma patterns revealed through sensation.

compassion.justification: Self-care implicit in practice but not explicit compassion training.

communication.justification: Less reactive nervous system may improve communication indirectly.

empathy.justification: Regulated nervous system may support empathy but not trained directly.

bodyAwareness.justification: Core of practice - tracking sensations is foundational skill.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Primary outcome - expanding window of tolerance. Pendulation teaches regulation.

act.researchBasis: Extensive RCT evidence; multiple meta-analyses; well-established therapy

adhd.justification: Defusion and values work helpful for ADHD. Some specific research. Addresses emotional components well.

depression.justification: Strong evidence base. A-Tjak et al. (2015) meta-analysis shows effectiveness. Values-based action counters avoidance.

anxiety.justification: Acceptance stance well-suited for anxiety. Multiple RCTs. Defusion from anxious thoughts.

trauma.justification: Acceptance framework helpful but not trauma-specific. Often combined with other approaches.
trauma.concerns: May need augmentation for complex trauma

focus.justification: Present-moment awareness is core process. Mindfulness component trains attention.

metacognition.justification: Cognitive defusion is highly metacognitive - observing thoughts as thoughts. Core ACT process.

insight.justification: Values clarification provides self-understanding. Understanding psychological inflexibility patterns.

compassion.justification: Self-as-context promotes self-compassion. Not explicit compassion training but implicit.

communication.justification: Values-guided action improves relationship behaviors. Less reactivity.

empathy.justification: Perspective-taking skill trained through self-as-context. Flexibility extends to understanding others.

bodyAwareness.justification: Some somatic awareness through mindfulness component but not primary focus.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Core outcome - psychological flexibility includes emotional flexibility. Strong evidence.

stoicism.researchBasis: Philosophical tradition; CBT connection provides indirect evidence; limited direct research

adhd.justification: Cognitive techniques may help with emotional regulation in ADHD. No direct research.

depression.justification: CBT (derived from Stoicism) has strong evidence. Reframing and acceptance reduce rumination.

anxiety.justification: Dichotomy of control directly addresses anxiety's focus on uncontrollables. CBT connection. Premeditatio malorum.

trauma.justification: Cognitive reframing alone insufficient for trauma. May intellectualize rather than process.

focus.justification: Attention to present moment emphasized. Prosoche (attention) is core practice.

metacognition.justification: Core practice is examining impressions and judgments. Highly metacognitive philosophy.

insight.justification: Self-examination central. Understanding one's judgments and values.

compassion.justification: Cosmopolitanism and oikeiosis extend care outward. But often perceived as emotionally detached.

communication.justification: Less reactivity improves communication. Philosophical training in rhetoric.

empathy.justification: Universal human nature understanding. But may prioritize equanimity over emotional attunement.

bodyAwareness.justification: Primarily cognitive practice. Body not emphasized in traditional or modern applications.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Core purpose - reducing pathological emotions through cognitive reappraisal. CBT evidence supports this mechanism.

metta.researchBasis: Strong research base; multiple RCTs; well-documented mechanisms

adhd.justification: Not attention-focused practice. May help with emotional aspects but not core ADHD symptoms.

depression.justification: Strong evidence for positive affect increase. Counters self-criticism central to depression. Zeng et al. (2015).

anxiety.justification: Less direct than mindfulness for anxiety but positive emotions buffer anxiety. Social anxiety specific benefits.

trauma.justification: Self-compassion component helpful. May need modification for complex trauma. Can activate attachment wounds.
trauma.concerns: May be difficult for trauma survivors initially

focus.justification: Some concentration required to maintain phrases/intentions but not systematic attention training.

metacognition.justification: Some awareness of mental states but less metacognitive than insight practices.

insight.justification: Traditional view: insight into nature of love/connection. But not systematic insight practice.
insight.concerns: Different type of insight than vipassana

compassion.justification: Primary purpose of practice. Strong evidence for compassion increases. Klimecki et al. brain changes.

communication.justification: Increased goodwill improves relationships. Less reactivity. Warmth in interactions.

empathy.justification: Directly trains empathic concern. Brain changes in empathy circuits documented.

bodyAwareness.justification: Heart area sometimes focused on, but primarily cognitive-affective practice.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Positive emotions provide regulation resources. Less direct than mindfulness but effective.

psilocybin-therapy.researchBasis: Multiple Phase 2/3 RCTs; breakthrough therapy designation; rigorous research

adhd.justification: No research on ADHD. May help with emotional comorbidities but not attention specifically.

depression.justification: Multiple RCTs show large effects for treatment-resistant depression. Carhart-Harris et al. breakthrough research.

anxiety.justification: Strong effects for cancer-related anxiety. Griffiths et al. showed sustained reductions.

trauma.justification: Promising but less researched than depression/anxiety. May facilitate trauma processing. Requires careful support.
trauma.concerns: Risk of overwhelm; needs trauma-informed protocol

focus.justification: Acute effects disrupt normal attention. Post-treatment attention not systematically studied.

metacognition.justification: Profound alterations in self-reflection. 'Ego dissolution' provides unique metacognitive perspective.

insight.justification: Mystical-type experiences reliably produce lasting insights. Rated as among most meaningful experiences.

compassion.justification: Increases in openness and prosocial behavior documented. Love/connection common themes.

communication.justification: Indirect benefits through reduced defensiveness. Not specifically studied.

empathy.justification: Increased emotional empathy documented. Nature relatedness increases suggest expanded concern.

bodyAwareness.justification: Somatic experiences during sessions. Integration may increase body awareness long-term.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Reduced emotional avoidance. May improve by addressing root causes rather than building skills.

circling.researchBasis: Primarily phenomenological reports; no RCTs; emerging practice

adhd.justification: Group format may be challenging for ADHD. Some attention training through sustained contact.
adhd.concerns: Speculative; may be difficult for ADHD

depression.justification: Connection and being seen may help depression. Counters isolation. No direct research.

anxiety.justification: Exposure to vulnerability may help social anxiety. But format may be anxiety-provoking initially.

trauma.justification: Relational healing potential but not trauma-specific. May activate attachment wounds without resolution.

focus.justification: Present-moment relational attention required. Some attention training through sustained contact.

metacognition.justification: Core practice involves noticing internal experience and naming it. Highly metacognitive framework.

insight.justification: Relational mirrors reveal blind spots. Self-understanding through others' experience of you.

compassion.justification: Being with others' experience without fixing. Holding space is compassionate practice.

communication.justification: Primary training ground for communication. Explicit practice of sharing impact, owning experience.

empathy.justification: Core skill is sensing into others' experience. Explicit empathic attunement practice.

bodyAwareness.justification: Noticing somatic experience part of practice. Relational-somatic connection emphasized.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Co-regulation through group container. Learning to stay present with difficult emotions.

nvc.researchBasis: Limited research; primarily training-based evidence; growing academic interest

adhd.justification: Communication framework not designed for ADHD. May help with relationship aspects.

depression.justification: Self-empathy component may help. Connection needs addressed. No direct research.

anxiety.justification: Identifying needs may reduce anxiety from unmet needs. No direct research.

trauma.justification: Self-empathy helpful but not trauma-specific. May help with relational trauma patterns.

focus.justification: Requires attention to distinguish observations, feelings, needs. Some training.

metacognition.justification: Requires distinguishing observations from evaluations, feelings from thoughts. Highly metacognitive framework.

insight.justification: Understanding underlying needs provides self-insight. Pattern recognition in conflicts.

compassion.justification: Core of practice - connecting with universal needs in self and others. Compassionate framework.

communication.justification: Primary purpose. Training studies show improved communication. Structured approach to difficult conversations.

empathy.justification: Empathic listening is core skill. Understanding others' needs without judgment.

bodyAwareness.justification: Feelings connected to body but not systematic somatic practice.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Needs framework helps with emotional understanding. Less reactive communication.

dbt.researchBasis: Extensive RCT evidence; gold standard for BPD; well-established protocol

adhd.justification: Adapted DBT for ADHD shows promise. Emotion regulation component particularly helpful.

depression.justification: Strong evidence especially for depression with suicidality. Harned et al. research.

anxiety.justification: Distress tolerance skills directly address anxiety. Evidence across populations.

trauma.justification: DBT-PTSD protocol shows effectiveness. Stabilization before trauma processing.

focus.justification: Mindfulness module trains attention. What/How skills explicit attention training.

metacognition.justification: Observing and describing skills are metacognitive. Emotion identification training.

insight.justification: Understanding emotion triggers and patterns. Behavioral chain analysis.

compassion.justification: Radical acceptance component. Self-validation emphasized. Less explicit than CFT.

communication.justification: Interpersonal effectiveness module explicitly trains communication. DEAR MAN, GIVE, FAST.

empathy.justification: GIVE skills train empathy in relationships. Validation skills.

bodyAwareness.justification: Some somatic mindfulness but less emphasis than body-based approaches.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Primary outcome and core module. Extensive evidence for emotion regulation improvement.

emdr.researchBasis: Extensive RCTs; WHO recommended for PTSD; well-established protocol

adhd.justification: Not designed for ADHD. May help if ADHD complicated by trauma.

depression.justification: Effective for depression with trauma component. Less evidence for depression without trauma.

anxiety.justification: Strong evidence especially for trauma-related anxiety. Phobia protocols effective.

trauma.justification: Primary indication. Multiple meta-analyses. WHO and APA recommended.

focus.justification: Not attention training. Dual attention required during processing but not trained.

metacognition.justification: Some awareness of cognitions/beliefs but not systematic metacognitive training.

insight.justification: Insights often emerge during processing. Adaptive resolution includes understanding.

compassion.justification: Self-compassion may emerge through processing. Not explicitly trained.

communication.justification: Not a communication intervention. May improve indirectly through reduced trauma symptoms.

empathy.justification: Trauma resolution may free up empathic capacity. Not directly trained.

bodyAwareness.justification: Body scan component. Tracking somatic experience during processing.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Reduced trauma reactivity is primary outcome. Less emotional hijacking.

hatha-yoga.researchBasis: Extensive research; multiple meta-analyses; well-documented physiological mechanisms

adhd.justification: Some studies show benefits. Movement component may help. Less evidence than for other conditions.

depression.justification: Multiple meta-analyses show moderate-large effects. GABA increases documented.

anxiety.justification: Strong evidence. Physiological mechanisms well-understood. Multiple meta-analyses.

trauma.justification: Trauma-sensitive yoga (TCTSY) has RCT evidence. Standard yoga needs modification.

focus.justification: Sustained attention required for poses. Some attention improvements documented.

metacognition.justification: Some awareness of body/mind but less metacognitive than meditation practices.

insight.justification: Self-understanding through body awareness. Less cognitive insight than meditation.

compassion.justification: Self-care through practice. Philosophical framework includes compassion.

communication.justification: Primarily solitary practice. Less reactivity may help indirectly.

empathy.justification: Increased body awareness may support empathy. Not directly trained.

bodyAwareness.justification: Primary purpose. Interoceptive awareness well-documented. Poses require body attention.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Strong evidence. Physiological regulation through nervous system. HRV improvements.

mussar.researchBasis: Limited empirical research; rich philosophical tradition; some longitudinal observational data

adhd.justification: Structured practice may help with self-regulation. Accountability partnerships provide external structure.

depression.justification: Gratitude and character cultivation may help. Community aspect counters isolation. No direct research.
depression.concerns: Based on general positive psychology principles

anxiety.justification: Trust (bitachon) practices address anxiety directly. Equanimity cultivation.

trauma.justification: Community support helpful. Not trauma-specific. May intellectualize.

focus.justification: Daily practice requires sustained attention. Focus on one trait at a time.

metacognition.justification: Core of practice - examining one's middot and motivations. Daily cheshbon hanefesh (soul accounting).

insight.justification: Self-examination central to practice. Understanding character patterns.

compassion.justification: Chesed (loving-kindness) is core middah. Explicit compassion cultivation.

communication.justification: Speech ethics (shmirat halashon) explicitly addressed. Accountability partnerships require communication.

empathy.justification: Multiple middot address empathy (rachamim, nosei b'ol). Explicit training.

bodyAwareness.justification: Primarily cognitive-behavioral practice. Body not emphasized.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Equanimity (menuchat hanefesh) explicitly cultivated. Anger management middot.

open-awareness.researchBasis: Growing research on non-dual awareness; taxonomy papers; some experimental studies

adhd.justification: Non-directive practice may be challenging for ADHD. Less structure than focused attention.
adhd.concerns: May be frustrating without concentration foundation

depression.justification: Spacious awareness may help with rumination. Acceptance of what is. Less studied than focused practices.

anxiety.justification: Not focusing on anxious content may reduce amplification. Equanimity development.

trauma.justification: Open awareness may encounter trauma material unexpectedly. Needs foundation and support.

focus.justification: Different type of attention - panoramic vs. focused. May develop after concentration practice.

metacognition.justification: Pure awareness of awareness. Highest metacognitive achievement in contemplative traditions.

insight.justification: Direct recognition of nature of mind. Profound insights reported.

compassion.justification: Compassion may arise naturally from non-dual perspective. Not explicitly trained.

communication.justification: Less reactivity may help. Solitary practice.

empathy.justification: Non-separation may enhance empathy. Reduced self-other boundary.

bodyAwareness.justification: Body included in open field but not specifically focused on.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Equanimity central to practice. Emotions arise and pass without reactivity.

idp.researchBasis: Based on adult development research; limited direct study of IDP practice; theoretical foundation strong

adhd.justification: Structured practice may help. Executive function development implicit.

depression.justification: Meaning-making may help existential aspects. Less direct than clinical interventions.

anxiety.justification: Perspective-taking may reduce anxiety through reframing. Not primary purpose.

trauma.justification: Cognitive development practice not appropriate for trauma processing.

focus.justification: Deliberate practice requires sustained attention. Journaling component.

metacognition.justification: Core skill - observing own meaning-making. Awareness of developmental assumptions.

insight.justification: Primary purpose - understanding own developmental position and limitations.

compassion.justification: Later stages associated with universal compassion. May develop through practice.

communication.justification: Perspective-taking improves communication. Understanding others' developmental positions.

empathy.justification: Multiple perspective-taking is empathy skill. Core developmental capacity.

bodyAwareness.justification: Primarily cognitive practice. Body not emphasized in most IDP approaches.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Later stages associated with better regulation. May develop through practice.

tm.researchBasis: Extensive research (some methodological concerns); large dataset; physiological markers well-documented

adhd.justification: Some studies show ADHD benefits. Travis research. Mantra provides structure.

depression.justification: Meta-analyses show moderate effects. Less studied than MBSR for depression specifically.

anxiety.justification: Strong evidence for anxiety reduction. Multiple meta-analyses.

trauma.justification: Some veteran studies. Not specifically trauma-focused. May help general regulation.

focus.justification: Effortless attention trained. Some attention research. Different from focused attention practices.

metacognition.justification: Awareness of transcending but less metacognitive than insight practices.

insight.justification: Transcendent experiences but not systematic insight development.

compassion.justification: May develop through reduced stress. Not explicitly trained.

communication.justification: Solitary practice. May help through reduced reactivity.

empathy.justification: Some research on social connection improvements. Indirect.

bodyAwareness.justification: Transcends body focus. Physical rest documented but not body awareness.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Well-documented stress reduction. Physiological regulation improvements.

mbct.researchBasis: Multiple RCTs; NICE recommended; well-established for depression relapse prevention

adhd.justification: Not designed for ADHD. Some attention training component.

depression.justification: Primary indication. Equivalent to maintenance antidepressants. Piet & Hougaard (2011) meta-analysis.

anxiety.justification: Strong evidence. Decentering from anxious thoughts. Multiple RCTs.

trauma.justification: Not designed for trauma. May help with depression/anxiety secondary to trauma.

focus.justification: Mindfulness component trains attention. Body scan, breath focus.

metacognition.justification: Core mechanism is metacognitive awareness. Thoughts as thoughts not facts.

insight.justification: Understanding depressive patterns. Cognitive insights combined with experiential learning.

compassion.justification: Some self-compassion development. Less explicit than compassion-focused approaches.

communication.justification: Not a communication intervention. May help through reduced reactivity.

empathy.justification: Increased emotional awareness may help. Not directly trained.

bodyAwareness.justification: Body scan included from MBSR. Early warning sign detection through body.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Core outcome. Preventing depressive relapse through early intervention.

tonglen.researchBasis: Traditional Tibetan practice; limited empirical research; some compassion meditation overlap

adhd.justification: Visualization practice. Some concentration required but not attention-focused.

depression.justification: Counters self-focus through other-orientation. Connection practice. No direct research on tonglen specifically.

anxiety.justification: May increase anxiety initially through suffering focus. Advanced practice.

trauma.justification: Taking in suffering may be activating. Need stable foundation. Can be healing when ready.

focus.justification: Visualization requires some concentration. Not systematic attention training.

metacognition.justification: Awareness of compassion process. Observing resistance to practice.

insight.justification: Insight into interconnection. Understanding nature of suffering.

compassion.justification: Primary purpose. Directly trains compassion through imaginative exchange.

communication.justification: Increased compassion may improve communication warmth.

empathy.justification: Direct training in feeling others' experience. Core mechanism.

bodyAwareness.justification: Breath-based practice includes some body awareness.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Learning to be with difficult emotions. Equanimity development.

zen.researchBasis: Some neuroimaging and attention research; less RCT evidence than MBSR; cultural translation challenges

adhd.justification: Breath counting requires sustained attention. Structured practice format.

depression.justification: Some research shows benefits. Less studied than MBSR for depression.

anxiety.justification: Present-moment focus reduces worry. Some research support.

trauma.justification: Not trauma-specific. May help through regulation. Can be intense.

focus.justification: Breath counting and shikantaza both train attention. EEG studies show attention changes.

metacognition.justification: Koan practice highly metacognitive. Observing mind's functioning.

insight.justification: Kensho/satori experiences. Direct realization of nature of mind.

compassion.justification: Bodhisattva vows frame practice. Less explicit than metta.

communication.justification: Dokusan (teacher interviews) trains communication. Primarily solitary.

empathy.justification: Non-separation understanding. May develop through practice.

bodyAwareness.justification: Posture emphasis. Full body awareness in shikantaza. Kinhin (walking).

emotionalRegulation.justification: Equanimity development. Less reactivity through sustained practice.

shamatha.researchBasis: Some retreat research (MacLean); overlaps with other concentration research

adhd.justification: Systematic attention training. Shamatha Project showed sustained attention improvements.

depression.justification: Calm states may help. Less directly addressing depression than insight practices.

anxiety.justification: Deep calm states reduce anxiety. May not address root patterns.

trauma.justification: Concentration can suppress material. Not designed for trauma work.

focus.justification: Primary purpose. Shamatha Project documented significant attention improvements.

metacognition.justification: High awareness of attention and its qualities. Monitoring mind state.

insight.justification: Provides platform for insight but not insight practice itself.

compassion.justification: Can use metta as object. Not primary purpose.

communication.justification: Solitary practice. May help through reduced reactivity.

empathy.justification: Equanimity may support empathy. Not directly trained.

bodyAwareness.justification: Breath focus includes some body awareness. Less emphasis than vipassana.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Calm abiding provides regulation. Access to settled states.

mdma-therapy.researchBasis: Phase 3 RCTs completed; FDA breakthrough therapy designation; rigorous methodology

adhd.justification: Not appropriate for ADHD. Single-session protocol not designed for attention.

depression.justification: Often improves with trauma resolution. Not primary indication but benefits documented.

anxiety.justification: Reduces avoidance. Benefits for trauma-related anxiety well-documented.

trauma.justification: Primary indication. Phase 3 trials show 67% no longer met PTSD criteria.

focus.justification: Altered state during session. Not attention-focused intervention.

metacognition.justification: Increased perspective on traumatic memories. Observing rather than reliving.

insight.justification: Profound insights into trauma patterns. Integration work captures insights.

compassion.justification: Self-compassion dramatically increases. Core mechanism for trauma healing.

communication.justification: Increased openness and trust. Therapeutic relationship deepens. Relationship benefits reported.

empathy.justification: Empathogenic substance. Increased emotional connection core effect.

bodyAwareness.justification: Somatic processing enabled. Reduced fear allows body awareness.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Trauma resolution primary outcome. Less emotional hijacking.

ayahuasca.researchBasis: Growing research; RCTs emerging; legal/access limitations affect research

adhd.justification: Not appropriate for ADHD. Ceremony format not designed for attention.

depression.justification: Palhano-Fontes RCT showed rapid antidepressant effects. Traditional use for depression.

anxiety.justification: May increase during ceremony. Long-term reductions documented.

trauma.justification: Traditional use for trauma. May facilitate processing. Needs skilled facilitation.

focus.justification: Altered state disrupts normal attention. Not attention intervention.

metacognition.justification: Profound self-reflection common. Witnessing own patterns from distance.

insight.justification: Core traditional use - 'teaching plant'. Deep insights reliably reported.

compassion.justification: Self-compassion and connection commonly reported. Community ceremony format.

communication.justification: Group ceremony may help. Primarily internal experience.

empathy.justification: Nature connection. Feeling interconnection with all life commonly reported.

bodyAwareness.justification: Strong somatic experience. Purging involves body. Integration may increase awareness.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Processing difficult emotions. Long-term regulation may improve.

ketamine-therapy.researchBasis: Extensive research; FDA approved (esketamine); well-documented mechanisms

adhd.justification: Not appropriate for ADHD. Dissociative mechanism not relevant.

depression.justification: Strong evidence for treatment-resistant depression. Rapid onset. FDA approved.

anxiety.justification: Benefits for anxiety often co-occurring with depression. Some specific research.

trauma.justification: Emerging research on PTSD. May facilitate reconsolidation. Less evidence than MDMA.

focus.justification: Dissociative effects during session. Not attention-focused.

metacognition.justification: Perspective shift on problems. Observing self from distance.

insight.justification: Insights common during sessions. Less reliably profound than psilocybin.

compassion.justification: May improve through depression relief. Not direct mechanism.

communication.justification: May improve with mood. Not direct benefit.

empathy.justification: Some reports of increased connection. Variable.

bodyAwareness.justification: Dissociation may reduce body awareness during. Variable long-term.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Depression relief improves regulation. BDNF/neuroplasticity mechanism.

tre.researchBasis: Limited RCT evidence; some pilot studies; strong physiological rationale

adhd.justification: Not designed for ADHD. Some regulation benefits may help.

depression.justification: Nervous system regulation may help. Limited research on depression specifically.

anxiety.justification: Direct nervous system discharge. Pilot studies show anxiety reduction.

trauma.justification: Designed for trauma. Completing defensive responses. Some pilot research.

focus.justification: Not attention-focused. Physical practice.

metacognition.justification: Primarily physical process. Not cognitive practice.

insight.justification: Some understanding may emerge through body. Not primary purpose.

compassion.justification: Self-care implicit. Not compassion training.

communication.justification: Physical practice. May help through reduced reactivity.

empathy.justification: Not empathy training. May free up capacity through regulation.

bodyAwareness.justification: Core of practice - attending to tremoring and sensations.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Primary mechanism - discharging held activation. Some research support.

qigong.researchBasis: Multiple systematic reviews; heterogeneous practices make research difficult; well-documented physiological effects

adhd.justification: Moving meditation may help. Limited ADHD-specific research.

depression.justification: Systematic reviews show benefits. Wang et al. (2014) review.

anxiety.justification: Strong evidence for anxiety reduction. Multiple reviews.

trauma.justification: Gentle somatic practice may help. Not trauma-specific.

focus.justification: Movement coordination requires attention. Some research support.

metacognition.justification: Some awareness of energy states. Less metacognitive than meditation.

insight.justification: Traditional view includes insight through practice. Not primary Western research focus.

compassion.justification: Some forms include compassion cultivation. Variable.

communication.justification: Primarily solitary physical practice.

empathy.justification: Energy sensitivity may include sensing others. Not primary focus.

bodyAwareness.justification: Core of practice - sensing qi and body state. Well-documented.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Strong evidence for physiological regulation. HRV improvements.

tai-chi.researchBasis: Extensive research; multiple Cochrane reviews; well-established benefits

adhd.justification: Form learning requires attention. Limited ADHD research.

depression.justification: Multiple systematic reviews show benefits. Wang et al. (2010).

anxiety.justification: Strong evidence base. Multiple reviews and RCTs.

trauma.justification: Gentle somatic practice. May help with regulation. Not trauma-specific.

focus.justification: Learning complex forms requires sustained attention. Some research.

metacognition.justification: Awareness of movement quality. Less metacognitive than meditation.

insight.justification: Traditional view includes wisdom. Not primary research focus.

compassion.justification: Philosophy includes compassion. Not primary training.

communication.justification: Push hands involves partner sensitivity. Most practice is solo.

empathy.justification: Push hands trains sensing others. Class setting may help.

bodyAwareness.justification: Core of practice. Slow movements require body attention. Well-documented.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Strong evidence. Physiological regulation. Stress reduction.

holotropic-breathwork.researchBasis: Limited empirical research; primarily phenomenological; developed from LSD therapy research

adhd.justification: Not appropriate for ADHD. Altered state experience.

depression.justification: Cathartic release may help. Some clinical reports. No RCTs.

anxiety.justification: May increase during session. Variable long-term effects.

trauma.justification: Designed to access and process unconscious material. Similar to psychedelic therapy rationale.

focus.justification: Altered state disrupts normal attention.

metacognition.justification: Witnessing experience from expanded perspective.

insight.justification: Primary purpose - accessing unconscious wisdom. Consistent reports.

compassion.justification: Self-compassion may emerge through release. Group container supportive.

communication.justification: Group sharing after session. Primarily internal experience.

empathy.justification: Sitter role trains empathic holding. May increase through experience.

bodyAwareness.justification: Intense somatic experience. Bodywork component. Core to process.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Cathartic release may improve regulation. Some research.

wim-hof.researchBasis: Some RCT evidence; physiological effects well-documented; limited psychological research

adhd.justification: Cold exposure may help arousal regulation. Breathing requires focus. Limited research.

depression.justification: Cold exposure shows mood benefits. Autonomic activation. Some research.

anxiety.justification: Learning to tolerate stress. Cold exposure trains distress tolerance.

trauma.justification: May be activating for trauma survivors. Not trauma-appropriate.

focus.justification: Breathing protocol requires concentration. Cold exposure demands attention.

metacognition.justification: Physical practice. Limited metacognitive component.

insight.justification: May have insight during practice. Not primary purpose.

compassion.justification: Self-discipline implicit. Not compassion training.

communication.justification: Solitary practice primarily.

empathy.justification: Not empathy training.

bodyAwareness.justification: Core of practice - breath and cold sensation awareness.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Autonomic regulation well-documented. Stress resilience training.

authentic-relating.researchBasis: Minimal formal research; phenomenological reports; emerging practice

adhd.justification: Group format may be challenging. Some attention training through contact.

depression.justification: Connection counters isolation. Being seen may help. No direct research.

anxiety.justification: Exposure to vulnerability. May increase before helping. Social anxiety specific.

trauma.justification: Relational healing potential. May activate attachment wounds.

focus.justification: Present-moment attention required. Different type of focus.

metacognition.justification: Noticing and naming internal experience is core skill.

insight.justification: Self-understanding through relational mirrors. Others reflect patterns.

compassion.justification: Holding space for others' experience. Non-judgment practice.

communication.justification: Primary purpose - explicit communication training through games.

empathy.justification: Core skill - sensing others' experience. Explicit practice.

bodyAwareness.justification: Somatic awareness included. Secondary to relational focus.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Co-regulation through group. Staying present with emotions.

sufism.researchBasis: Traditional wisdom; limited empirical research; some phenomenological studies

adhd.justification: Dhikr requires repetition which may help. Not ADHD-specific.

depression.justification: Love and connection central. Community support. No direct research.

anxiety.justification: Trust in divine may reduce anxiety. Surrender practice.

trauma.justification: Community and spiritual support. Not trauma-specific.

focus.justification: Dhikr concentration practice. Heart focus.

metacognition.justification: Self-observation in muraqaba. Watching states.

insight.justification: Core purpose - gnosis (ma'rifa). Direct knowledge of divine.

compassion.justification: Divine love central. Compassion as expression of love.

communication.justification: Poetry and teaching traditions. Community sharing.

empathy.justification: Love of creation. Seeing divine in others.

bodyAwareness.justification: Whirling and movement practices. Heart awareness.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Surrender and acceptance practices. Equanimity development.

vedanta.researchBasis: Ancient philosophical tradition; limited empirical research; primarily textual/experiential

adhd.justification: Primarily intellectual inquiry. May be challenging for ADHD.

depression.justification: Reframing identity may help existential depression. Limited direct benefit for clinical depression.

anxiety.justification: Recognizing unchanging self reduces identity-based anxiety.

trauma.justification: Intellectual practice not appropriate for trauma processing.

focus.justification: Self-inquiry requires sustained attention.

metacognition.justification: Core practice - discriminating observer from observed. Highly metacognitive.

insight.justification: Primary purpose - insight into nature of self. Jnana yoga.

compassion.justification: Non-dual realization implies compassion. Unity consciousness.

communication.justification: Satsang (truth speaking) tradition. Less reactivity.

empathy.justification: Seeing self in all beings. Non-separation.

bodyAwareness.justification: Primarily intellectual/spiritual inquiry. Body transcended.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Witness consciousness reduces reactivity.

christian-contemplation.researchBasis: Some research on centering prayer; rich contemplative tradition; clinical applications emerging

adhd.justification: Sacred word provides focus point. Some attention training.

depression.justification: Connection to transcendent. Self-compassion through divine love.

anxiety.justification: Surrender and trust practices. Some centering prayer research shows benefits.

trauma.justification: Divine support may help. Not trauma-specific.

focus.justification: Centering prayer trains attention through sacred word.

metacognition.justification: Observing thoughts and returning to center. Similar to mindfulness.

insight.justification: Contemplative insight tradition. Lectio divina.

compassion.justification: Divine love central. Extending love to others.

communication.justification: Community context. Prayer partnerships.

empathy.justification: Love of neighbor. Seeing Christ in others.

bodyAwareness.justification: Primarily interior/spiritual focus. Body less emphasized.

emotionalRegulation.justification: Surrender and acceptance. Equanimity through faith.

highConfidenceScores: MBSR, MBCT, DBT, ACT for depression/anxiety
Yoga, Tai Chi, Qigong for body awareness and emotion regulation
lowConfidenceScores: Newer relational practices (Circling, AR) - need empirical research
Traditional practices (Mussar, Sufism, Vedanta) - limited modern research
Specific ADHD ratings - limited research for most practices
Communication/empathy ratings for non-relational practices - often extrapolated
generalCaveats: Scores represent estimates based on available evidence and theoretical plausibility
Individual variation is substantial - what works for one person may not work for another
Implementation quality matters - same practice poorly taught may show different results
Combination/sequencing effects not captured - practices may work better in combination
Cultural context and meaning affect outcomes - transferring practices across cultures may change effectiveness
Research often done on modified/secularized versions - traditional forms may differ
recommendedImprovements: Commission systematic reviews for under-researched practices
Develop standardized outcome measures across traditions
Examine moderators (who benefits most from which practice)
